Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Each ticket follows a sequence of activities: Receive Ticket, Triage, Assign to Level-1 Agent, Investigate Issue, Resolve Ticket, Close Ticket. However, some cases, such as 102 and 105, include escalations to Level-2 agents, which may introduce delays that are absent in other cases.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The stated problem identifies prolonged resolution times as an indicator of performance issues. Therefore, tickets with significantly longer durations (such as Case 105's 49 hours and 55 minutes) must be analyzed for underlying causes, including delays between specific steps or escalations.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: By reviewing patterns across tickets with varying total times, it becomes evident that escalation to Level-2 agents frequently correlates with longer durations, as seen in cases 102 and 105. However, Case 102's faster resolution after escalation shows that not all escalations inherently result in delays.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: A potential cause for delays could be inefficiencies in handling escalations, such as prolonged coordination with Level-2 teams or delays in transitioning cases back to Level-1 after escalation is resolved.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Case 105's event log, which includes an escalation on March 1 and no further progress until an investigation on March 2, supports the hypothesis that escalation bottlenecks may be a root cause. Similarly, observing other cases like 102 confirms that prompt handling of escalations can mitigate such delays.

Name: Counterfactual Reasoning - IND
Text: If Case 105 had avoided escalation to Level-2 agents, it might have resolved faster, similar to Case 101 or 103, which both resolved within 1.5 hours without any escalation.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The resolution delays in Case 105 and 102 are consistent with the assumption that dependency-related bottlenecks arise when escalating to higher-tier agents. The data suggests that optimizing escalation handling could reduce durations.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Tickets with escalations, particularly those involving Level-2 agents (like Case 105), tend to have significantly longer times. Therefore, a rule of thumb would be to focus on optimizing escalations to reduce such durations.
